conclusion: Analyzing forces in both scenarios to find the friction force.
Figure A shows block A on an inclined plane with θ = 37°.
Weight component parallel to the plane is M g sin 37°.
Weight component perpendicular to the plane is M g cos 37°.
Maximum static friction is f_max = μ M g cos 37°.
Since the block is just about to slide, f_max = M g sin 37°.
μ M g cos 37° = M g sin 37°, therefore μ = sin 37° / cos 37° = 0.75.
Coefficient of static friction is μ = 0.75.
Figure B shows block A and cylinder B on an inclined plane with θ = 30°.
Block A has mass M and cylinder B has mass m, with M = 4m.
Weight component parallel to plane for cylinder B is m g sin 30°.
Weight component perpendicular to plane for cylinder B is m g cos 30°.
Normal force from block A is N_A.
Normal force from inclined plane is N_plane.
Weight component parallel to plane for block A is M g sin 30°.
Weight component perpendicular to plane for block A is M g cos 30°.
Normal force from cylinder B is N_B, equal in magnitude to N_A but opposite direction.
Friction force from inclined plane is f, which needs to be found.
For cylinder equilibrium, N_plane + N_A cos α - m g cos 30° = 0.
For cylinder equilibrium, N_A sin α - m g sin 30° = 0.
For block A equilibrium, N_B cos α - M g cos 30° = 0.
For block A equilibrium, f - M g sin 30° - N_B sin α = 0.
Since N_B = N_A and M = 4m, solve for friction force f.
